title: Was Helter Skelter by The Beatles the first heavier sounding rock song? Why or why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not even close. Hendrix, Cream, and others pre-dated The White Album. Helter Skelter’s actually fairly pathetic compared with how “heavy” other bands were carrying on. There was this Beatle song that pre-dated Hendrix and Cream. It was just their third (consecutive) #1 hit in the US. It’s kind of like a Phil Spector “wall of sound” thing except John Lennon thought hmmmm. Wall of guitars? The racket they got out of those big Vox amps must have been ungodly. Add Ringo pounding a decidedly heavy beat and you had one of the key proto-heavy rock songs. It’s hard to find the original single online — you should have heard this blasting out of your mom’s car radio. It was like an eruption. From April, 1965 . . . turn it up!

No. There were bands recording heavy rock songs in 1964 when The Beatles were recording songs like “Love Me Do.” The Kinks released “You Really Got Me” & “All Day & All Of The Night” in 1964. The Yardbirds had debuted the year before. The Who were already active then also. “Helter Skelter” was recorded in an attempt to out heavy The Who on “I Can See For Miles.” They didn’t succeed. “Helter Skelter” is one of the most tuneless songs in The Beatles catalogue. The Beatles recorded a lot of great melodic pop & rock music, but heavy rock music? Not so much. “Rain” was probably the most interesting heavier rock tune they recorded.
